actions_taken: 11:07 - Alert for increased latency on DC1-DC2 path
11:10 - Checked metrics, latency jumped from 12ms to 90ms
11:15 - Ran traceroute, found unexpected routing via transit ISP
11:18 - Checked BGP routing table, primary WAN link still up
11:20 - Discovered BGP route flapping on primary path
11:25 - Investigated further, found asymmetric routing issue
11:30 - Identified BGP peer session instability with ISP
11:35 - Contacted ISP NOC, reported BGP flapping
11:40 - ISP resolved BGP peering issue on their side
11:45 - Verified routing returned to optimal primary path
11:50 - Confirmed latency back to baseline, incident closed
resolution_summary: ISP resolved BGP peering instability that caused traffic to route through suboptimal transit path
engineer_notes: BGP route flapping caused traffic to temporarily route through backup ISP transit link, adding 75ms of latency. Primary WAN link was technically 'up' but BGP session was unstable. ISP found configuration drift on their BGP router. This highlights need for better BGP session monitoring and alerting on route changes, not just link status.
